questions.question: What kind of data structure does SMA* search use?

explanations.c: Nodes are expanded in order of their f values.

questions.question: Is SMA* an informed or uninformed search algorithm?

explanations.a: The heuristic function is problem-specific knowledge to help 'inform' solutions

questions.question: In SMA* search, what is the role of the heuristic function?

answers.a: Estimates distance from the start node to the current node.
answers.b: Estimates the cost of the cheapest path from the current node to the goal node.
answers.c: Estimates distance from the start node to the goal node.
answers.d: Estimates the cost of the cheapest path from the start node to the goal node.

questions.question: In SMA* search, what does the f value represent?

answers.a: It represents the heuristic value of the current node.
answers.b: It represents the cost of the cheapest path found from the current node to the goal node.
answers.c: It represents the actual cost of the path from the start node to the current node.
answers.d: It represents the sum of the actual cost from the start node to the current node and the estimated cost from the current node to the goal node.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about SMA* search?

answers.c: It is never complete nor optimal.
answers.d: It is complete if enough memory is available to store the shallowest solution.

questions.question: When could SMA* perform worse than breadth-first search?

answers.a: When the heuristic function is not admissible
answers.b: When the heuristic function is consistent
answers.c: When the search space is infinite
answers.d: When the cost of the optimal solution is high

explanations.a: SMA* may unnecessarily expand nodes and find suboptimal solutions.
explanations.b: SMA* would be optimal under this condition.
explanations.c: SMA* is still better than breadth-first search in this case.
explanations.d: SMA* would still be optimal under this condition.
